  <title>
   The future of birth control and drug delivery: Remote controlled implants that last for 16 years | ExtremeTech
  </title>
  <link href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/185871-the-future-of-birth-control-and-drug-delivery-remote-controlled-implants-that-last-for-16-years" rel="canonical"/>

  <link href="http://www.extremetech.com/feed" rel="alternate" title="RSS" type="application/rss+xml"/>
  <meta content="text/html; charset=utf-8" http-equiv="Content-Type"/>
  <meta content="An MIT spin-off in Massachusetts, backed by the Gates Foundation, has developed a small, remote-controlled drug-dispensing implant that sits just ..." name="description"/>
  <link href="http://mobile.extremetech.com/electronics/221637-the-future-of-birth-control-and-drug-delivery-remote-controlled-implants-that-last-for-16-years" media="only screen and (max-width: 670px)" rel="alternate"/>
  <meta content="The future of birth control and drug delivery: Remote controlled implants that last for 16 years | ExtremeTech" property="og:title"/>
  <meta content="ExtremeTech" property="og:site_name"/>
  <meta content="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/185871-the-future-of-birth-control-and-drug-delivery-remote-controlled-implants-that-last-for-16-years" property="og:url"/>
  <meta content="An MIT spin-off in Massachusetts, backed by the Gates Foundation, has developed a small, remote-controlled drug-dispensing implant that sits just under your skin. Such an implant could be used to dispense a whole range of useful drugs -- but in this case, one of the first commercial applications will be the contraceptive hormone levonorgestrel. A single implant can apparently provide enough levonorgestrel to be effective for 16 years; currently, no implanted contraceptive works for more than five years." property="og:description"/>
  <meta content="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/drug-dispensing-contraceptive-chip.jpg" property="og:image"/>
  <meta content="summary_large_image" name="twitter:card"/>
  <meta content="ExtremeTech" name="twitter:site"/>
  <meta content="@ExtremeTech" name="twitter:creator"/>
  <meta content="extremetech.com" name="twitter:domain"/>
  <meta content="The future of birth control and drug delivery: Remote controlled implants that last for 16 years | ExtremeTech" name="twitter:title"/>
  <meta content="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/185871-the-future-of-birth-control-and-drug-delivery-remote-controlled-implants-that-last-for-16-years" name="twitter:url"/>
  <meta content="An MIT spin-off in Massachusetts, backed by the Gates Foundation, has developed a small, remote-controlled drug-dispensing implant that sits just under your skin. Such an implant could be used to dispense a whole range of useful drugs -- but in this case, one of the first commercial applications will be the contraceptive hormone levonorgestrel. A single implant can apparently provide enough levonorgestrel to be effective for 16 years; currently, no implanted contraceptive works for more than five years." name="twitter:description"/>
  <meta content="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/drug-dispensing-contraceptive-chip.jpg" name="twitter:image:src"/>
  <meta content="185871" name="zdid"/>

	           var q = {};
	           if (!url) {
	                 return {};
	           }
	            url.replace(/([^?=&amp;]+)(=([^&amp;]*))?/g, function ($0, $1, $2, $3) { q[$1] = $3; });
	            return q;
	  };

  </script>

  <link href="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-includes/wlwmanifest.xml" rel="wlwmanifest" type="application/wlwmanifest+xml"/>
  <link href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/185865-scientists-discover-the-on-off-switch-for-human-consciousness-deep-within-the-brain" rel="prev" title="Scientists discover the on-off switch for human consciousness deep within the brain"/>
  <link href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/185789-toyota-develops-high-efficiency-free-piston-no-crankshaft-combustion-engine-to-power-an-ev" rel="next" title="Toyota develops high-efficiency free piston no-crankshaft combustion engine to power an EV"/>

    }
  }

   </script>

          #stickybanner,

           googletag.cmd.push(function() { googletag.display('TopBanner'); });
          </script>

           <a href="http://pubads.g.doubleclick.net/gampad/jump?iu=/4585/zd.extech/computingsection_ATF&amp;t=zdid%3D185871%26cmn%3Dzd&amp;sz=970x250|728x90&amp;template=article&amp;c=9118837&amp;tile=1">

     <div id="main">
      <div class="add-nav">
       <ul class="breadcrumbs" id="breadcrumbs">
        <!-- Breadcrumb NavXT 5.1.1 -->
        <li class="home">
         <a href="http://www.extremetech.com" title="Go to ExtremeTech.">
          ExtremeTech
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span typeof="v:Breadcrumb">
          <a class="taxonomy category" href="http://www.extremetech.com/category/computing" property="v:title" rel="v:url" title="Go to the Computing category archives.">
           Computing
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li class="current_item">
         The future of birth control and drug delivery: Remote controlled implants that last for 16 years
        </li>
       </ul>
      </div>
      <div class="twocolumns">
       <div id="content">
        <div class="article">
         <div class="title">
          <h2>
           The future of birth control and drug delivery: Remote controlled implants that last for 16 years
          </h2>
          <ul>
           <li>
            <span class="by vcard">
             By
             <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/author/santhony" rel="author" title="Posts by Sebastian Anthony">
              Sebastian Anthony
             </a>
             on July 7, 2014 at 11:13 am
            </span>
           </li>
           <li class="comments">
            <a data-disqus-identifier="185871 http://www.extremetech.com/?p=185871" href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/185871-the-future-of-birth-control-and-drug-delivery-remote-controlled-implants-that-last-for-16-years#disqus_thread">
             <span>
              Comment
             </span>
            </a>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </div>
         <div class="content">
          <span id="intelliTXT" name="intellitxt">
           <img alt="Microchips, drug dispensing implant contraceptive thing" class="attachment-full wp-post-image" height="353" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/drug-dispensing-contraceptive-chip-640x353.jpg" width="640"/>
           <div class="photo">
            <div class="box2">
             <h3>
              Share This article
             </h3>
             <div class="addthis_sharing_toolbox">
             </div>
            </div>
           </div>
           <p>
            An MIT spin-off in Massachusetts, backed by the Gates Foundation, has developed a small, remote-controlled drug-dispensing implant that sits just under your skin. To activate the drug dispenseryou simply press a button on a wireless remote control  and press it again to turn it off. Such an implant could be used to dispense a whole range of useful drugs  but in this case, one of thefirst commercial applications will be thecontraceptive hormone
            <span style="color: #000000;">
             levonorgestrel, which is already used by a number of female birth control methods. A single implant can apparently provide enoughlevonorgestrel to be effective for 16 years; currently, no implanted contraceptive works for more than five years.
            </span>
           </p>
           <p>
            The implanted device, developed by the rather unimaginatively named Microchips in Lexington, is 20mm (0.8in) square and 7mm thick. Contained within the device is a microchip (thus the companys amazing name) that contains a series of drug reservoirs. This is where the magic occurs: Each reservoir is gated by a special titanium and platinum seal that temporarily melts when an electric current is applied, allowing the drug to seep out. Apparently the reservoirs are large enough to carry a 16-year supply of the hormonal contraceptive
            <span style="color: #000000;">
             levonorgestrel.
            </span>
           </p>
           <p>
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/technology_infographic.jpg">
             <img alt="Microchips implant drug dispensing infographic diagram thing" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-185874" height="504" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/technology_infographic.jpg" width="384"/>
            </a>
           </p>
           <p>
            If 16 years of continued contraception wasnt cool enough, the implant can also be activated and deactivated wirelessly. So, the implant would continue to provide birth control  until you press a button on a remote control, in which case it would be turned off, and you could then get pregnant again. Sadly, exact details on how the implant actually works  most notably the wireless connectivity and the magical melting/re-forming seal  are fairly hard to come by. But, considering its based on tech that MIT pioneered way back in the late 90s, and now the involvement of the Gates Foundation, presumably it all works as advertised.
           </p>
           <p>
            So far, the Microchips implant has been successfully used to dispense drugs to osteoporosis patients. Now, with the Gates Foundation getting involved,the new contraceptive version of the implant is being developed. The current plan is to begin testing in 2015 and have it on the market by 2018. (Remember, the Gates Foundation is all about improving the quality of life for people living in developing countries, and reliable contraception is key to such an endeavor. Last year we wrote a fantastic story about the Foundation funding the creation of
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/171417-bill-gates-funds-creation-of-thin-light-impenetrable-graphene-condoms">
             an impenetrable graphene condom
            </a>
            )
           </p>
           <div class="wp-caption alignnone" id="attachment_185875" style="width: 650px">
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/microchips-implant.jpg">
             <img alt="Microchips implant" class="size-large wp-image-185875" height="897" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/microchips-implant-640x897.jpg" width="640"/>
            </a>
            <p class="wp-caption-text">
             An older Microchips implant (I think it measures around 5cm on the longest side.)
            </p>
           </div>
           <p>
            The obvious advantage of such a drug-dispensing implant is that it removes a large portion of the potential human error. Rather than having to take a pill every day, or visit a doctor for an injection every few months, the implant just sits there, dutifully dispensing drugs for 16 years. If you decide its the right time to get pregnant, just push the button. Theres no mention of it on the Microchips website, but presumably a male version could also be developed (though male hormonal contraceptives arent quite as developed yet as their female counterparts).
           </p>
           <p>
            As with any medical implant, my mind readily races towards possible flaws and misuses of the Microchips technology. Obviously the wireless remote control is only useful if it remains in the hands of the woman with the implant.You also cant rule out the possibility of outside actors remotely hacking the implant to turn it off  so the woman might think shes protected, butisnt. The possibilities get even scarier when you consider that these implants might eventually be used for other drugs, too. It was almost three years ago that we first discussed
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/92054-black-hat-hacker-details-wireless-attack-on-insulin-pumps">
             the lethal wireless insulin pump hack
            </a>
            .
           </p>
           <p>
            Imagine a future, where everyone is equipped with a range of drug-dispensing implants that lay dormant until theyre needed. Feeling the onset of flu? Just push a button to dispense some drugs. Got food poisoning? Push the button. Feeling down and need a quick boost of serotonin? Mmm, warm and fuzzy button. Need to kill someone quickly and remotely? Hack one of their drug dispensing implants.
           </p>
          </span>
         </div>
         <div class="articles-list">
          <div class="holder">
           <div class="widget column widget_execphp" id="execphp-45">
            <div data-page-type="article" data-placement="Below Article Thumbnails - Article -gtd" id="taboola-below-article-thumbnails">
            </div>
            <script type="text/javascript">
             window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
      _taboola.push({
        mode: 'thumbnails-a',
        container: 'taboola-below-article-thumbnails',
        placement: 'Below Article Thumbnails - Article -gtd',
        target_type: 'mix'
      });
            </script>
            <div data-page-type="article" data-placement="Below Article Text Links - Article -gtd" id="taboola-below-article-text-links">
            </div>
            <script type="text/javascript">
             window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
      _taboola.push({
        mode: 'hybrid-text-links-a',
        container: 'taboola-below-article-text-links',
        placement: 'Below Article Text Links - Article -gtd',
        target_type: 'mix'
      });
            </script>
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="articles-list">
         <div class="holder">
          <div class="widget column widget_tagswidget" id="tagswidget-2">

             </li>

           </div>
          </div>
          <div class="widget column widget_disquswidget" id="disquswidget-3">
           <script type="text/javascript">
            var disqus_developer = 1;
           </script>
           <div class="title">
            <span class="count">

            </span>

             Post a Comment
            </h3>
           </div>

                 </p>

                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-308261">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-308261">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-308261">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-308261">
                    Brian Kram
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-308261">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-308261">
                   <p>
                    I Imagine using something like NFC would work fairly well
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">
                  <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-308265">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-308265">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-308265">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-308265">
                      Sean Lumly
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-308265">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-308265">
                     <p>
                      Thats a great idea! If the dispenser was close enough to be affected by an NFC transmitter, this would reduce the likelihood of mischievousness  any attempts to hack the chip would have to be extremely close range.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Maybe we need another near proximity wireless technology with around 30cm (1ft) of range. Something using magnetic fields might work, though error checking would have to be very robust to deal with interference.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                  </li>
                  <!-- #comment-## -->
                 </ul>
                 <!-- .children -->
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
               </ul>
               <!-- .children -->
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-307905">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-307905">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-307905">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-307905">
                  Ivor OConnor
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-307905">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-307905">
                 <p>
                  Bet this will be hacked and misused if it ever comes into existence.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  The endless possible deadly failures I wonder if it would survive the TSA screening process. Or an X-Ray. Or all the other stuff. It surely wont survive deliberate hacking. Maybe it will help get world population under control and back down to about a billion people?
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>

              <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-307928">

                  BillBasham
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-307928">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-307928">
                 <p>
                  Drastically setting aside my libertarian beliefs so I can propose a solution to poverty.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  We need a 3 key unlock mechanism on a mandated birth control implant.  1&amp;2 the prospective parents, and the 3rd keyed to a trust fund with adequate funding to raise the child to adulthood
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">

                   </p>

Offer someone $10,000 for every 5 years they manage to not have children and we could solve a lot of problems.  This implant system could be a good tool for this sort of scheme.
                     </p>
                    </div>

                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-308272">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-308272">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-308272">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-308272">
                    MarcB1969
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-308272">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-308272">
                   <p>
                    Youre thinking is in line with current Science Czar, John Holdren and Aldous Huxley. Holdren suggested a similar idea in his book, Ecoscience, while Huxley provided guidelines for who was allowed to procreate in Brave New World.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    I shared similar sentiments many years ago, but over time realized that nature has its own intrinsic genius in sorting these things out. Its best for Man not to meddle with it. The way to prevent the less fit from procreating is to simply stop subsidizing it.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </li>

              <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-308035">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-308035">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-308035">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-308035">
                  BrettTGonzalez
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-308035">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-308035">
                 <p>
                  A single implant can apparently provide enough levonorgestrel to be effective for 16 years; currently, no implanted contraceptive works for more than five years.
                  <a href="http://num.to/264-974-592-824" rel="nofollow">
                   http://num.to/264-974-592-824
                  </a>
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->

                   <ul class="children">
                    <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-308505">
                     <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-308505">
                      <cite id="dsq-cite-308505">
                       <span id="dsq-author-user-308505">
                        Joel Detrow
                       </span>
                      </cite>
                     </div>
                     <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-308505">
                      <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-308505">
                       <p>
                        Make sure you dont have that in your personal autocorrect library, because its not a word.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                    </li>
                    <!-- #comment-## -->
                   </ul>
                   <!-- .children -->
                  </li>
                  <!-- #comment-## -->
                 </ul>
                 <!-- .children -->
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
               </ul>
               <!-- .children -->
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-308123">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-308123">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-308123">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-308123">
                  Lolmuxica
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-308123">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-308123">
                 <p>
                  Imagine being limited and tied to a 16 years old technology.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Would be like being forced to carry a Pentium II processor, or a 1998 Motorola cell phone
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <a href="http://s3.amazonaws.com/rapgenius/motorola-m3788-1998.jpg" rel="nofollow">
                   http://s3.amazonaws.com/rapgenius/motorola-m3788-1998.jpg
                  </a>
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-308268">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-308268">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-308268">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-308268">
                  MarcB1969
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-308268">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-308268">
                 <p>
                  Tech like this is another sign that humans are rapidly supplanting a previous reliance on religion with an unquestioned faith in science. Thanks, but no thanks.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-308320">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-308320">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-308320">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-308320">
                  larry
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-308320">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-308320">
                 <p>
                  Women will go for it. I hope it reaches markets in teh U.S.. Sadly, theyll never put in a permission slip from say the husband. Women are alway saying; you got me pregnant. What this needs is a male permission slip. Since it takes two to get prego. I say give the man some help here. How about a near field identifier. Want to have sex; honestly honey. my machine is on (not lying). They could sell tons of these things for guys; to check and see if the girl is protected. All we need is the govt to install them in every women seeking free birth control at taxpayer expense. Honestly what would be the rub. The woman pushes the remote control; and the guy gets a message saying its on and protecting. Perfect ending for those wishing to use control measures.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-308758">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-308758">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-308758">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-308758">
                  Mo Lillaney
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-308758">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-308758">
                 <p>
                  Its a better idea to make this a design patent, and have the chip close to the surface of the skin such that you can inject the reservoirs with any kind of drug youd like. many drugs wont last 16 years, but the design concept is more valuable then anything also if you are burning the gates open to let the medicine outthese arent reusable so it would need tweaking to be refillable
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
             </ul>
            </div>
           </div>
           <script type="text/javascript">
            /* &lt;![CDATA[ */
    var disqus_url = 'http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/185871-the-future-of-birth-control-and-drug-delivery-remote-controlled-implants-that-last-for-16-years';
    var disqus_identifier = '185871 http://www.extremetech.com/?p=185871';
    var disqus_container_id = 'disqus_thread';
    var disqus_domain = 'disqus.com';
    var disqus_shortname = 'extremetech';
    var disqus_title = "The future of birth control and drug delivery: Remote controlled implants that last for 16 years";
        var disqus_config = function () {
        var config = this; // Access to the config object
        config.language = '';

        /*
           All currently supported events:
            * preData  fires just before we request for initial data
            * preInit - fires after we get initial data but before we load any dependencies
            * onInit  - fires when all dependencies are resolved but before dtpl template is rendered
            * afterRender - fires when template is rendered but before we show it
            * onReady - everything is done
         */

        config.callbacks.preData.push(function() {
            // clear out the container (its filled for SEO/legacy purposes)
            document.getElementById(disqus_container_id).innerHTML = '';
        });
                config.callbacks.onReady.push(function() {
            // sync comments in the background so we don't block the page
            var script = document.createElement('script');
            script.async = true;
            script.src = '?cf_action=sync_comments&amp;post_id=185871';

            var firstScript = document.getElementsByTagName( "script" )[0];
            firstScript.parentNode.insertBefore(script, firstScript);
        });
                    };
/* ]]&gt; */
           </script>
           <script type="text/javascript">
            /* &lt;![CDATA[ */
    var DsqLocal = {
        'trackbacks': [
        ],
        'trackback_url': "http:\/\/www.extremetech.com\/extreme\/185871-the-future-of-birth-control-and-drug-delivery-remote-controlled-implants-that-last-for-16-years\/trackback"    };
/* ]]&gt; */
           </script>
           <script type="text/javascript">
            /* &lt;![CDATA[ */
(function() {
    var dsq = document.createElement('script'); dsq.type = 'text/javascript';
    dsq.async = true;
    dsq.src = '//' + disqus_shortname + '.' + 'disqus.com' + '/embed.js?pname=wordpress&amp;pver=2.74';
    (document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0] || document.getElementsByTagName('body')[0]).appendChild(dsq);
})();
/* ]]&gt; */
           </script>

       <div class="widget column widget_execphp" id="execphp-46">
        <script type="text/javascript">
         window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
    _taboola.push({flush: true});
    
    var __ZDTABEVENT = {
        accountid : "",
        init : function(acct) {
            __ZDTABEVENT.accountid = acct;
            var divs = document.querySelectorAll("div[id^=taboola]"), i=divs.length;
            while (i--) {
                divs[i].addEventListener("click", __ZDTABEVENT.clkevt);
                __ZDTABEVENT.track(divs[i].id, "imp");
            }
        },
        clkevt : function(evt){
            __ZDTABEVENT.track(evt.currentTarget.id, "clk");


        },
        track : function(id,evt) {
            var el = document.getElementById(id);
            var placement = el.getAttribute('data-placement');
            var pagetype = el.getAttribute('data-page-type');
            if(window.ga) window.ga('send', 'event', 'Taboola', pagetype + '-' + placement, evt);
            if(window._gaq) window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'Taboola', pagetype+'-'+placement, evt, undefined, true]);
            if (__ZDDMP) { __ZDDMP.Event({signal:'taboola', pubid: __ZDTABEVENT.accountid, ptype:pagetype, placement:placement, evt:evt});}
        }
    };
    __ZDTABEVENT.init('ziffdavis-network15-extremetech');
        </script>
       </div>

         <img alt="" height="1" src="http://zdbb.net/l/z0WVjCBSEeGLoxIxOQVEwQ/" width="1"/>
        </noscript>
        <!-- end zdbb -->
        <!-- begin ns -->
        <script type="text/javascript">
         (function() {
    var nstrack = document.createElement("script"), el_nstrack = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0]; nstrack.async = true;
    nstrack.src = "http://track.netshelter.net/async/js/sites/extremetech.com-async.js";
    el_nstrack.parentNode.insertBefore(nstrack, el_nstrack);
  })();

       <div class="widget column widget_execphp" id="execphp-15">
        <!-- START Parse.ly Include: Standard -->
        <div id="parsely-root" style="display: none">
         <div data-parsely-site="extremetech.com" id="parsely-cfg">
         </div>
        </div>
        <script>
         (function(s, p, d) {
  var h=d.location.protocol, i=p+"-"+s,
      e=d.getElementById(i), r=d.getElementById(p+"-root"),
      u=h==="https:"?"d1z2jf7jlzjs58.cloudfront.net"
      :"static."+p+".com";
  if (e) return;
  e = d.createElement(s); e.id = i; e.async = true;
  e.src = h+"//"+u+"/p.js"; r.appendChild(e);
})("script", "parsely", document);
        </script>
        <!-- END Parse.ly Include -->
       </div>
       <div class="widget column widget_execphp" id="execphp-17">
        <!-- Vibrant Ads -->
        <script type="text/javascript">
         if (ZDXI.IsIntl()) {
	document.write('&lt;scr'+'ipt type="text/javascript" src="http://extremetech.us.intellitxt.com/intellitxt/front.asp?ipid=5281"&gt;&lt;/scr'+'ipt&gt;');
}
        </script>
        <!-- End Vibrant Ads -->
       </div>
       <div class="widget column widget_execphp" id="execphp-26">
        <!-- chartbeat -->
        <script type="text/javascript">
         var _sf_async_config = _sf_async_config || {};
/** CONFIGURATION START **/
&lt;!-- set in head --&gt;
_sf_async_config.sections = 'Computing'; 
_sf_async_config.authors ='Sebastian Anthony';
/** CONFIGURATION END **/
(function(){
function loadChartbeat()
{ window._sf_endpt=(new Date()).getTime(); var e = document.createElement('script'); e.setAttribute('language', 'javascript'); e.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript'); e.setAttribute('src', '//static.chartbeat.com/js/chartbeat.js'); document.body.appendChild(e); }

var oldonload = window.onload;
window.onload = (typeof window.onload != 'function') ?
loadChartbeat : function()
{ oldonload(); loadChartbeat(); }

;
})();
        </script>
       </div>

    }

         unused
        </div>
        <script type="text/javascript">
         jQuery(document).ready(function() {
  setTimeout(function() {
  if (jQuery("#adsense").height() &lt; 8) { 
    if (window._gaq) { window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'AdBlocker','Blocked' ,undefined, undefined, true]); }
    if (window.ga) { window.ga('send', 'event', 'AdBlocker', 'Blocked'); }
  } else {
    if (window._gaq) { window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'AdBlocker','NotBlocked' ,undefined, undefined, true]); }
    if (window.ga) { window.ga('send', 'event', 'AdBlocker', 'NotBlocked' ); }
    }
	}, 2000);
});
        </script>

  <script type="text/javascript">
   // &lt;![CDATA[
        var disqus_shortname = 'extremetech';
        (function () {
            var nodes = document.getElementsByTagName('span');
            for (var i = 0, url; i &lt; nodes.length; i++) {
                if (nodes[i].className.indexOf('dsq-postid') != -1) {
                    nodes[i].parentNode.setAttribute('data-disqus-identifier', nodes[i].getAttribute('rel'));
                    url = nodes[i].parentNode.href.split('#', 1);
                    if (url.length == 1) url = url[0];
                    else url = url[1]
                    nodes[i].parentNode.href = url + '#disqus_thread';
                }
            }
            var s = document.createElement('script'); s.async = true;
            s.type = 'text/javascript';
            s.src = '//' + 'disqus.com/forums/' + disqus_shortname + '/count.js';
            (document.getElementsByTagName('HEAD')[0] || document.getElementsByTagName('BODY')[0]).appendChild(s);
        }());

  </script>
